name: shirt
content:
shirt

noun
 
 
/ʃɜːt/
 
/ʃɜːrt/
Idioms
jump to other results
  1. enlarge image
    a piece of clothing worn on the upper part of the body, made of light cloth, with sleeves and usually with a collar and buttons down the front
    • to wear a shirt
    • a white/blue/red shirt
    • He had a shirt and tie on.
    • a long-sleeved/short-sleeved shirt
    • an open-necked shirt
    • a button-down shirt
    • a cotton/flannel/silk shirt
    • She took a pen from her shirt pocket.
    • a football shirt
    • in a shirt A man in a striped shirt sat alone in the corner.
    see also aloha shirt, dress shirt, hair shirt, Hawaiian shirt, nightshirt, polo shirt, stuffed shirt, sweatshirt, T-shirt
    Extra Examples
    • He tucked his shirt into his pants.
    • He wears a crisp white shirt to the office every day.
    • a footballer's shirt number
    • I grabbed him by the collar of his shirt.
    • He was dressed in a loose fitting shirt and pants.
    • He pulled on his shirt and ran down to see what had happened.
    Topics Clothes and Fashiona1
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • clean
    • crisp
    • fresh
    • …
    verb + shirt
    • button
    • button up
    • unbutton
    • …
    shirt + noun
    • button
    • collar
    • cuff
    • …
    phrases
    • shirt and tie
    See full entry
    Word OriginOld English scyrte, of Germanic origin; related to Old Norse skyrta (compare with skirt), Dutch schort, German Schürze ‘apron’, also to short; probably from a base meaning ‘short garment’.
Idioms
keep your shirt on
  1. (informal) used to tell somebody not to get angry
    • Keep your shirt on! It was only a joke.
put your shirt on somebody/something
  1. (British English, informal) to bet all your money on somebody/something
    • It's a good horse, but I wouldn't put my shirt on it.
the shirt off somebody’s back
  1. anything that somebody has, including the things they really need themselves, that somebody else takes from them or they are willing to give
    • He was the type of person who would give you the shirt off his back.
See shirt in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: shirt

name: T-shirt
content:
T-shirt

noun
 
 
/ˈtiː ʃɜːt/
 
/ˈtiː ʃɜːrt/
(also tee shirt)
jump to other results
  1. enlarge image
    an informal shirt, usually with short sleeves (= arms) no collar or buttons, or just a few buttons at the top
    • He was wearing a faded pair of blue jeans and an old T-shirt.
    • a sleeveless/long-sleeved T-shirt
    Topics Clothes and Fashiona1
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • baggy
    • loose
    • oversized
    • …
    See full entry

name: dress shirt
content:
dress shirt

noun
 
/ˈdres ʃɜːt/
 
/ˈdres ʃɜːrt/
jump to other results
  1. a white shirt worn on formal occasions with a bow tie and suit
  2. (North American English) a smart shirt with long sleeves that can be worn with a tie

/ˌheə ˈʃɜːt/
 
/ˌher ˈʃɜːrt/

name: shirt front
content:
shirt front

noun
 
/ˈʃɜːt frʌnt/
 
/ˈʃɜːrt frʌnt/
jump to other results
  1. the front part of a shirt, especially the stiff front part of a formal white shirt
    • I usually end up with gravy down my shirt front.

name: shirt tail
content:
shirt tail

noun
 
/ˈʃɜːt teɪl/
 
/ˈʃɜːrt teɪl/
jump to other results
  1. the lower part of a shirt that is usually inside your trousers
    • He ran out of the house, his tie in his hand and his shirt tail hanging out.
